entry.title: Combined summary - Exploring Network Rule Changes
entry.summary: The Bitcoin community has received a guide that explores the problems of changing consensus system rules, which has been posted on the Bitcoin Development mailing list for review. The guide categorizes changes into three categories: Addition of a new rule (Soft-Fork), Removal of an old rule (Hard-Fork), and Subverting an old rule (“Evil”, Non-Traditional Soft-Fork). There are two types of activations: External Activations (User Activated) and Internal Activations (Miner Activated, PoS Activated, Internal Governance Model, etc.). Users within the system with more important roles may wish to signal or veto about a particular topic. This could be part of the activation strategy (internal activations), or just simply to quantify the support of the upcoming change. There are two core types of Signalling: Optional and Forced, with two styles of Signalling: Normal Signalling (Opt-In) and Veto (Opt-Out). It is essential to understand these categories and types while making decisions about altering the rules of a consensus system.
